newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul stocks end higher, buying interest fizzles.
newsitem.headline: Seoul stocks end higher, buying interest fizzles.

text.p: Stocks closed higher on Friday on buying of small individual shares, induced by hopes of changes to the real-name system, brokers said.
But they said general investor interest fizzled on fears of weakening market fundamentals, including high interest rates.
The composite index closed 3.11 points higher at 681.22.
"The initial fever chilled as investors realised the process of correcting the financial system would take some time," said a Hyundai Securities broker.
The yields on three-year corporates, South Korea's benchmark rates, rose to 12.53 percent on Friday from 12.50 on Thursday.
Trading volume totalled 37.38 million shares, compared with 41.27 million on Thursday.
Gainers outpaced losers 478 to 336 with 105 unchanged.
Brokers said expectations that the foreign shareholding limit would be expanded from April waned as the government showed no signs of such moves.

"The market will be dull next week if the expansion of the limit is delayed," said Choo Hee-yup of Dongwon Securities. "Falling customer deposits with securities houses are also a cause of concern." Such deposits were now estimated at 2.81 trillion won, down from 3.05 trillion in mid-February.
Shares in Shinhwa Co, a small telecommunications equipment producer, went limit-up after the company announced an ambitious sales plan. Shinhwa rose 1,400 won to its limit of 19,400.
The company said its sales would reach 180 billion won this year from 35 billion in 1996, helped by the development of a communication and tracking device for vehicles.

Shares in Woo Sung Food and Honam Food were halted for trading on news that the companies were selling parts of their operations to Coca-Cola Korea Bottling Co, a unit of Coca-Cola Co, the Korea Stock Exchange said.
Woo Sung closed 1,900 won higher at 25,900, Honam rose 1,500 won to 27,500.
Kyung Dong City Gas, which began trading for the first time on Friday, rose 3,200 won to 43,200.
Brokers said foreign investors unwound bank shares because of a dim view of recovery in the banking industry, which was hit by the Hanbo Steel failure.
Foreigners were estimated to have sold about 700,000 bank shares, brokers said.
The won's weakness against the dollar also helped keep foreign investors in the sidelines, they said.
